intro: Rorippa pseudoislandica, commonly known as the island watercress, is a small, aquatic or semi-aquatic flowering plant native to parts of Asia. It typically grows in wetlands, marshes, and along the edges of ponds and streams. The plant has slender, branching stems that are often submerged or floating, with small, lance-shaped leaves that are usually submerged or floating as well. It produces tiny white or pale yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The species is part of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other mustard plants.
